awd_titl_txt: Strategic Initiatives on Animal Welfare Challenges in Research and Education on Wildlife, Non-Model Species and Biodiversity
awd_abstract_narration:
The responsible and thoughtful care and use of animal in research, testing, training, and education is important from a moral and ethical point of view, as well as for the collection of high-quality, replicable data. The mission of ILAR is to identify, develop, promote, and disseminate strategies and practices that provide for excellence in the welfare of animals in academic or industry research, training, and education. This award serves to provide renewed support for core mechanisms through which ILAR accomplishes its mission. ILAR developed and continues to update the "Guide to the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals", a document that is the basis for governmental regulations on animal care and use in research and education, and that sets performances standards and best practices in animal care and use worldwide. ILAR also produces reports that provide the basis of guidelines and policy development for the care and use of animals in specific research domains. Further, ILAR oversees the content of the ILAR Journal, and ILAR is responsible for the ILAR Roundtable on Science and Welfare in Laboratory Animal Use, which organizes workshops on timely animal welfare-related issues of interest to research communities as well as government, industry, and professional societies, and whose outcomes ILAR disseminates worldwide. Additionally, through its role as a collaborating center for laboratory animal science and welfare of the World Animal Health Organization, ILAR influences animal welfare awareness and best practices in laboratory animal medicine and science worldwide. ILAR operations are carried out by ILAR staff working under the oversight of ILAR Council, which includes representatives from academia, industry, biomedical and wildlife research, veterinarian medicine, and safety and regulatory affairs.

The specific ILAR activities supported through this award include listening sessions, workshops, and similar activities  in preparation for revision of the “Guide”, so that the next edition of this crucial document covers a broader scope, one that also includes informed guidelines, standards, and ethical and welfare concerns for non-traditional research animals, wildlife, research in the field and other non-laboratory settings, and research using a wider range of approaches than traditionally employed in laboratory settings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine’s Board on Animal Health Sciences, Conservation, and Research (BAHSCR), formerly the Institute of Laboratory Animal Research (ILAR), works to advance rigorous, innovative, and inclusive scientific approaches for informed decision-making toward the goal of improving the health and wellbeing of the animal kingdom including humans and ecosystems. BAHSCR facilitates and accelerates interdisciplinary research and knowledge exchange related to critical scientific, societal, and policy challenges in the health and wellbeing of animals, humans, and ecosystems, including the responsible stewardship of animals involved in science.

BAHSCR provides advice on research occurring in clinical settings, laboratories, zoological institutions, and aquaria, and in wild and semi-wild environments. BAHSCR provides leadership within the National Academies and broader scientific community on the care and welfare of animals involved in research all of these settings.

BAHSCR strives to facilitate an understanding of the broader impact of animal health in all areas of the life and biomedical sciences, veterinary medicine, and conservation and biodiversity. ILAR, now BAHSCR, received core support to support the Standing Committee on the Care and Use of Animals in Research, Roundtable on the Science and Welfare of Animals in Research, and the meetings of the board, formerly the ILAR Council. Core support for BAHSCR supports core board functions including: a) anticipate emerging scientific, clinical, and policy issues associated with the health and wellbeing of animals, research involving animals, and complementary scientific methodologies; b) develop project concepts to address critical, emerging issues identified; and c) address a diversity of science and welfare of animals involved in research.

During the project, ILAR transitioned into BAHSCR around its 70th anniversary and initiated visioning exercises with the board members to develop a strategic vision, mission, objectives, and priority focal areas. BAHSCR’s vision is to advance rigorous, innovative, and inclusive scientific approaches for informed decision-making toward improving the health and wellbeing of the animal kingdom including humans and ecosystems. Its mission is to facilitate and accelerate interdisciplinary research and knowledge exchange toward addressing critical scientific, societal, and policy challenges in the health and wellbeing of animals, humans, and ecosystems, and support responsible stewardship of animals involved in science. The strategic objectives developed to guide BAHSCR’s current and future work are: a)  leverage interdisciplinary and community partnerships to enhance stewardship of animals involved in all areas of science; b) address critical ethical, policy, economic, workforce, and other societal issues associated with science involving animals; c) provide objective analysis of research and innovations in science involving animals; d) anticipate needs for innovative approaches and complementary methodologies for science involving animals; and e) engage international experts to address animal health, human health, and conservation. Within this framework, BAHSCR seeks to proactively facilitate discussions and develop projects in four strategic areas: a) interconnected health of animals, humans, and ecological systems; b) advances in animal and human health research to improve physical, mental, and social health of animals and their environments; c) research involving animals to improve physical, mental, and societal health of people and their environments; and d) merging issues affecting or otherwise involving animals. Bi-annually, BAHSCR identifies critical and foundational topics to address a variety of issues important to both the United States and international community, including scientific progress, animal health, human health, and ecological protection.

Reaching these scientific, veterinary and human clinical, and policy audiences is part of the broader impact of BAHSCR’s work. BAHSCR facilitated the Standing Committee’s listening sessions about what needs to be updated in the Guide on the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals and the workshop Future Topical Updates to the “Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals”, which partly was supported by funds from this NSF project, engaged numerous experts and organizations across academia, industry, scientific societies, and government. These discussions informed the preparation of the statement of task for updating the Guide. Subsequent discussions raised questions about including guidance for care and use of animals in non-laboratory research settings, including wild and semi-wild environments, zoos, and aquaria in the Guide. BAHSCR also considered the need for developing a new document that standardizes existing guidelines and adds new guidelines for research in these non-laboratory environments.

BAHSCR’s broader impact on the scientific community, policy community, and society extends beyond the outcomes of projects and board meetings to a diversity of interested groups in our work. We actively include scientists from various backgrounds, experiences, disciplines, sectors, and institutions to serve as committee members, subject matter experts, and/or reviewers on our boards and/or project committees; hire staff from a diversity of backgrounds; and view all project goals and objectives through a diversity lens. Through these efforts, BAHSCR provides a voice for animal health, care, and welfare experts with a diversity of perspectives and experiences to lend their knowledge and expertise to scientific, policy, and societal debates.
